answers.answer: The risk of developing a UTI is significantly higher in woman of all ages compared to men and the risk continues to increases with age.  Recurrent UTIs are caused by either reemergence of bacteria from a site within the urinary tract (bacterial persistence) or new infections from bacteria outside the urinary tract (reinfection).  Postmenopausal women can have recurrent UTI due to reinfections. These infections are sometimes attributable to incomplete emptying of the bladder, which is often associated with bladder or uterine prolapse.  Additionally, concurrent illness, such as diabetes, recent antibiotic use, spermicidal use, reduced flow due to obstruction can also increase the likelihood of infection.Infection not associated with positive cultures, urologic evaluation should be performed.  It is reasonable to have another cystoscopy, a post void residual (to evaluate the volume of urine remaining in the bladder after urinating) and functional imaging of your urinary tract.  The goal is to rule out cause of irritative bladder symptoms.There are a number of options for the long term treatment of recurrent UTI.  Some possible options include antibiotic prophylaxis, consisting of long courses of bactrim and/or nitrofurantoin, low does cephalexin or cipro.  Another option is to have self start antibiotics, where you would start antibiotics yourself as soon as you begin to experience symptoms.Ultimately the treatment should be a decision made between you and your urologist.

question: Every three months I have a UTI.  I say seem because there are no symptoms except extreme fatigue and a few red blood cells in my urine.  I drink at least 8 glasses of water a day and cultures never come up with any white blood cells..except once in a great while.  I've been struggling with this now for 10 years.  I'm becoming resistant to Cipro.   My doctor did find a few polyps which he removed and I was symptom free for about a year.  I'm back to every three months being incapacitated, in and out of bed all day long.  Should I go for another cystoscopy?  My doctor never seems very concerned about this.  I know there are worse problems, but it is affecting "my golden years".  Thank so much for your opinion.
title: UTI symptoms?
